children.value: There are two levels of animation in G6:
GLobal animation: Transform the graph animatively when the changes are global;
Item animation: The animation on a node or an edge.
The global animation is controlled by Graph instance. It takes effect when some global changes happen, such as:
when instantiating a graph to achieve it. And the
is the configurations for the animate, see
// Boolean, whether to activate the animation when global changes happen
// Number, the duration of one animation
All the built-in nodes and edges are static withou animation. To animate node or edge, please register your type of
The animation frames are applied on one graphics shape of a node. We are going to introduce this part by three demos:
The graphics animation (Left of the figure below);
The background animation (Center of the figure below);
Partial animation (Right of the figure below).
The code of the three demos can be found at:
In this example, we are going to magnify and shrink the node.
We first find the graphics shape to be animated by
. Here we find the 0th graphics shape of this type of node. Then, we call
for the node to define the properties for each frame(The first parameter is a function which returns the properties of each frame; the second parameter defines the configuration for animation, see
// Get the first graphics shape of this type of node
// Returns the properties for each frame. The input parameter ratio is a number that range from 0 to 1. The return value is an object that defines the properties for this frame.
// The properties for this frame. Only radius for this example
// The duration of one animation is 3000
// This custom node extend the built-in node 'circle'. Except for the rewrited afterDraw, other functions will extend from 'circle' node
You can add extra shape with animation in
of this demo, we draw three background circle shape with different filling colors. And the

is called for magnifying and fading out the three circles. We do not use set the first parameter as a function here, but assign the target style for each animation to the input paramter: magify the radius to 10 and reduce the opacity to 0.1. The second parameter defines the configuration for the animation, see
// must be assigned in G6 3.3 and later versions. it can be any value you want
// must be assigned in G6 3.3 and later versions. it can be any value you want
// must be assigned in G6 3.3 and later versions. it can be any value you want
// Sort the graphic shapes of the nodes by zIndex
// Magnify the first circle and fade it out
// Magnify the second circle and fade it out
// Magnify the third circle and fade it out
In this demo, we add extra graphics shape(an image) in
, and set a rotation animation for it. Note that the rotation animation is a little complicated, which should be manipulated by matrix. The first parameter of
is a function which returns the properties of each frame; the second parameter defines the configuration for animation, see
// must be assigned in G6 3.3 and later versions. it can be any value you want
// Returns the properties for each frame. The input parameter ratio is a number that range from 0 to 1. The return value is an object that defines the properties for this frame.
// The properties of this frame. Only target matrix for this demo
We are going to introduce this part by three demos:
A circle move along the edge (Left of the figure below);
A running dashed line (Center of the figure below. The gif may look like a static edge due to the low fps problem. You can check out the demo by link);
A growing line (Right of the figure below).
The code of the three demo can be found in:
In this demo, we add a circle shape with moving animation in
. In each frame, we return the relative position of the circle on the edge. The first parameter of
is a function which returns the properties of each frame; the second parameter defines the configuration for animation, see
// Get the first graphics shape of this type of edge, which is the edge's path
// The start point of the edge's path
// must be assigned in G6 3.3 and later versions. it can be any value you want
// Add the animation to the red circle
// Returns the properties for each frame. The input parameter ratio is a number that range from 0 to 1. The return value is an object that defines the properties for this frame
// Get the position on the edge according to the ratio
// Return the properties of this frame, x and y for this demo
The running dashed line is achieved by modifying the
in every frame. The first parameter of
is a function which returns the properties of each frame; the second parameter defines the configuration for animation, see
// Returns the configurations to be modified in this frame. Here the return value contains lineDash and lineDashOffset
A growing edge can also be implemented by calculating the
is a function which returns the properties of each frame; the second parameter defines the configuration for animation, see
// Returns the properties for each frame. The input parameter ratio is a number that range from 0 to 1. The return value is an object that defines the properties for this frame
G6 allows user to add animation for the interaction. As showin in the figure beow, when the mouse enters the node, the related edges will show the dashed line animation.
The code for the demo can be found in:
This kind of animation is related to the
to response the state changing. When the mouse enters a node, some state of the related edges are activated. The
of the edges activate the animation once it receive the state changing. The steps are:
in custom edge, and listen to the state changing in this function;
of the nodes to activate the state of the related edges.
The code below is a part of the code in
. Please note that we have omit some code to emphasize the code related to the animation.
is a function which returns the properties of each frame; the second parameter defines the configuration for animation, see
// Register a type of edge named 'can-running'
// When the running state is turned to be true
// Returns the configurations to be modified in this frame. Here the return value contains lineDash and lineDashOffset
// When the running state is turned to be false
// Listen the mouseenter event on node
// Get the target node of the event
// Get the related edges of the target node
// Turn the running state of all the related edges to be true. The setState function will be activated now
// Listen the mouseleave event on node
// Get the target node of the event
// Get the related edges of the target node
// Turn the running state of all the related edges to be false. The setState function will be activated now
, the animation should be stopped and the
The easing function for the animation, see
Callback function after the animation finish
Callback function after the animation is paused by shape.pause()
Callback function after the animation is resume by shape.resume()
G6 supports all the easing functions in d3.js. Thus, the options of
